title: Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 United States presidential election
Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 United States presidential election
deleted: * [[Voter ID laws in the United States]]

title: Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 United States presidential election
added: In March 2021, several Republican lawmakers introduced [https://www.ncleg.gov/BillLookUp/2021/S326 Senate Bill 326], also known as the "Election Integrity Act", which would reduce the amount of time voters have to turn in absentee ballot requests by one week, require absentee ballots be received by 5pm on [[Election Day]] (existing law allows ballots that are turned into the [[US Post Office|Post Office]] by Election Day to be received by county officials up to three days after Election Day), and prohibit county boards of election and the state board of election from accepting private donations to administer elections.<ref name="NSJ">{{Cite web|last=Dillon|first=A.P.|date=24 March 2021|title=Election Integrity Act filed at NC General Assembly|url=https://nsjonline.com/article/2021/03/election-integrity-act-filed-at-nc-general-assembly/|url-status=live|website=[[North State Journal]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Kampis|first=Johnny|date=23 March 2021|title=Election Integrity Act would require that absentee ballots be turned in sooner|url=https://www.carolinajournal.com/news-article/election-integrity-act-would-require-that-absentee-ballots-be-turned-in-sooner/|url-status=live|website=Carolina Journal}}</ref> It would also set aside $5 million from the state's General Fund to help those without a photo ID obtain one (North Carolina requires a photo ID to vote).<ref name="NSJ"/> Several Democrats have registered their opposition to the bill, with State Senator [[Donald G. Davis|Don Davis]] ([[Democratic Party (US)|D]]) saying "I believe that we should make it easier. If that ballot is cast by Election Day, then that ballot should be counted."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Choi|first=Cindy|date=19 March 2021|title=N.C. political science experts break down absentee ballots and the Election Integrity Act|url=https://www.witn.com/2021/03/19/nc-political-science-experts-break-down-absentee-ballots-and-the-election-integrity-act/|url-status=live|website=[[WITN-TV]]}}</ref>

title: Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 United States presidential election
added: In March 2021, several Republican lawmakers introduced [https://www.ncleg.gov/BillLookUp/2021/S326 Senate Bill 326], also known as the "Election Integrity Act", which would reduce the amount of time voters have to turn in absentee ballot requests by one week, require absentee ballotstobe received by 5pm on [[Election Day]] (existing law allows ballots that are turned into the [[US Post Office|Post Office]] by Election Day to be received by county officials up to three days after Election Day), and prohibit county boards of election and the state board of election from accepting private donations to administer elections.<ref name="NSJ">{{Cite web|last=Dillon|first=A.P.|date=24 March 2021|title=Election Integrity Act filed at NC General Assembly|url=https://nsjonline.com/article/2021/03/election-integrity-act-filed-at-nc-general-assembly/|url-status=live|website=[[North State Journal]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Kampis|first=Johnny|date=23 March 2021|title=Election Integrity Act would require that absentee ballots be turned in sooner|url=https://www.carolinajournal.com/news-article/election-integrity-act-would-require-that-absentee-ballots-be-turned-in-sooner/|url-status=live|website=Carolina Journal}}</ref> It would also set aside $5 million from the state's General Fund to help those without a photo ID obtain one (North Carolina requires a photo ID to vote).<ref name="NSJ"/> Several Democrats have registered their opposition to the bill, with State Senator [[Donald G. Davis|Don Davis]] ([[Democratic Party (US)|D]]) saying "I believe that we should make it easier. If that ballot is cast by Election Day, then that ballot should be counted."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Choi|first=Cindy|date=19 March 2021|title=N.C. political science experts break down absentee ballots and the Election Integrity Act|url=https://www.witn.com/2021/03/19/nc-political-science-experts-break-down-absentee-ballots-and-the-election-integrity-act/|url-status=live|website=[[WITN-TV]]}}</ref>

title: Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 United States presidential election
added: President [[Joe Biden]] has called Republican voting efforts "un-American" and "sick" and compared them to [[Jim Crow]] voting restrictions.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Garrison|first=Joey|last2=Barry|first2=Deborah Barfield|date=25 March 2021|title='It's sick': Biden slams Republican efforts in state legislatures to limit voting rights|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/03/25/its-sick-joe-biden-slams-state-gop-efforts-limit-voting-rights/7001372002/|url-status=live|website=[[USA Today]]}}</ref>

title: Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 United States presidential election
added: On March 24, 2021, Michigan Republicans introduced a package of 39 election reform bills that would introduce new restrictions to voting access.<ref name="DFP">{{Cite web|last=Boucher|first=Dave|last2=Hendrickson|first2=Clara|date=24 March 2021|title=Michigan GOP senators file 39 election reform bills Democrats call racist, based on lies|url=https://www.freep.com/story/news/politics/elections/2021/03/24/michigan-senate-gop-election-reform-laws/6963314002/|url-status=live|website=[[Detroit Free Press]]}}</ref> The bills would limit the availability of [[ballot box|ballot drop boxes]], require photo ID when applying for an absentee ballot, prohibit absentee ballot applications from being made available online, block unsolicited absentee ballot applications from being mailed out en masse, ban clerks from supplying prepaid return postage for absentee ballots, and prohibit the counting of absentee ballots before [[Election Day]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gallagher|first=Dianne|last2=LeBlanc|first2=Paul|date=24 March 2021|title=Michigan Republicans push for sweeping voting restrictions with new election bills|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/24/politics/michigan-election-bills-voting-rights/index.html|url-status=live|website=[[CNN]]}}</ref><ref name="DFP"/>

title: Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 United States presidential election
added: On March 24, 2021, Michigan Republicans introduced a package of 39 election reform bills that would introduce new restrictions to voting access,<ref name="DFP">{{Cite web|last=Boucher|first=Dave|last2=Hendrickson|first2=Clara|date=24 March 2021|title=Michigan GOP senators file 39 election reform bills Democrats call racist, based on lies|url=https://www.freep.com/story/news/politics/elections/2021/03/24/michigan-senate-gop-election-reform-laws/6963314002/|url-status=live|website=[[Detroit Free Press]]}}</ref> targeting in particular forms of voting that were the focus of former President Donald Trump's [[attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Mauger|first=Craig|date=24 March 2021|title=Republicans seek Michigan election law changes after 2020 losses|url=https://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/politics/2021/03/24/republicans-seek-michigan-election-law-changes-after-2020-losses/6982647002/|url-status=live|website=[[The Detroit News]]}}</ref> The bills would limit the availability of [[ballot box|ballot drop boxes]], require photo ID when applying for an absentee ballot, prohibit absentee ballot applications from being made available online, block unsolicited absentee ballot applications from being mailed out en masse, ban clerks from supplying prepaid return postage for absentee ballots, and prohibit the counting of absentee ballots before [[Election Day]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gallagher|first=Dianne|last2=LeBlanc|first2=Paul|date=24 March 2021|title=Michigan Republicans push for sweeping voting restrictions with new election bills|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/24/politics/michigan-election-bills-voting-rights/index.html|url-status=live|website=[[CNN]]}}</ref><ref name="DFP"/>

title: Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 United States presidential election
added: On March 24, 2021, Michigan Republicans introduced a package of 39 election reform bills that would introduce new restrictions to voting access,<ref name="DFP">{{Cite web|last=Boucher|first=Dave|last2=Hendrickson|first2=Clara|date=24 March 2021|title=Michigan GOP senators file 39 election reform bills Democrats call racist, based on lies|url=https://www.freep.com/story/news/politics/elections/2021/03/24/michigan-senate-gop-election-reform-laws/6963314002/|url-status=live|website=[[Detroit Free Press]]}}</ref> targeting in particular forms of voting that were the focus of former President Donald Trump's [[attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election]](which focused heavily on Michigan and five other six [[swing state]]s).<ref>{{Cite web|last=Mauger|first=Craig|date=24 March 2021|title=Republicans seek Michigan election law changes after 2020 losses|url=https://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/politics/2021/03/24/republicans-seek-michigan-election-law-changes-after-2020-losses/6982647002/|url-status=live|website=[[The Detroit News]]}}</ref> The bills would limit the availability of [[ballot box|ballot drop boxes]], require photo ID when applying for an absentee ballot, prohibit absentee ballot applications from being made available online, block unsolicited absentee ballot applications from being mailed out en masse, ban clerks from supplying prepaid return postage for absentee ballots, and prohibit the counting of absentee ballots before [[Election Day]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gallagher|first=Dianne|last2=LeBlanc|first2=Paul|date=24 March 2021|title=Michigan Republicans push for sweeping voting restrictions with new election bills|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/24/politics/michigan-election-bills-voting-rights/index.html|url-status=live|website=[[CNN]]}}</ref><ref name="DFP"/>

title: Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 United States presidential election
added: Republicans in Nevada have proposed a bill ([https://legiscan.com/NV/text/AB163/id/2305478 AB 163]) that would require require voters to provide proof of identity at the polls and require absentee ballots to be received by 7 p.m. on [[Election Day]] (under existing law, as long as ballots are turned into the [[US Post Office|Post Office]] by Election Day they are accepted up to a few days after Election Day).<ref name="CBS-local-NV">{{Cite web|last=Charms|first=David|date=22 February 2021|title=Nevada Republicans introduce voter identification bill; law would also require dead voters’ names be scrubbed|url=https://www.8newsnow.com/news/politics/nevada-republicans-introduce-voter-identification-bill-law-would-also-require-dead-voters-names-be-scrubbed/|url-status=live|website=[[KLAS-TV]]}}</ref> It also includes a provision requiring the Nevada Secretary of State to crosscheck the names of dead Nevadans with voter registration lists at least once a month, likely prompted by former President [[Donald Trump]]'s false claims that over 1,500 deceased people voted in Nevada in the [[2020 presidential election]].<ref name="CBS-local-NV"/>

Nevada was one of six states targeted by [[Donald Trump]] and his Republican allies in their [[Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election|attempt to overturn the 2020 presidential election]]. However, with Democrats in charge of both chambers of the legislature and the governor's office, Republican election bills have almost no chance of passing.<ref name="CBS-local-NV"/>

title: Republican efforts to restrict voting following the 2020 United States presidential election
added: Republicans in Nevada have proposed a bill ([https://legiscan.com/NV/text/AB163/id/2305478 AB 163]) that would require voters to provide proof of identity at the polls and require absentee ballots to be received by 7 p.m. on [[Election Day]] (under existing law, as long as ballots are turned into the [[US Post Office|Post Office]] by Election Day they are accepted up to a few days after Election Day).<ref name="CBS-local-NV">{{Cite web|last=Charms|first=David|date=22 February 2021|title=Nevada Republicans introduce voter identification bill; law would also require dead voters’ names be scrubbed|url=https://www.8newsnow.com/news/politics/nevada-republicans-introduce-voter-identification-bill-law-would-also-require-dead-voters-names-be-scrubbed/|url-status=live|website=[[KLAS-TV]]}}</ref> It also includes a provision requiring the Nevada Secretary of State to crosscheck the names of dead Nevadans with voter registration lists at least once a month, likely prompted by former President [[Donald Trump]]'s false claims that over 1,500 deceased people voted in Nevada in the [[2020 presidential election]].<ref name="CBS-local-NV"/>
